title: NCLTs will take nearly 10 years to clear pending cases at current rate: Economic Survey of India
NCLT Ahmedabad Admits Takshashila Heights Into CIRP After Supreme Court Order
NCLT Mumbai Orders Reconsideration Of Modified Resolution Plan By Highest Bidder In Logistics Company Insolvency
Pledged Shares Already With Creditor Need Not Be Returned During CIRP: NCLT Mumbai
Supreme Court Refuses To Interfere With NCLAT Order Upholding CIRP Against Air Travel Enterprises
Homebuyers Acting As Resolution Applicants Cannot Challenge CIRP Framework After Filing Plan: NCLT Kochi

Whether, after approval of Resolution Plan, Adjudicating Authority (NCLT) has jurisdiction to allow a claim arising from supplies made during the CIRP, which was not placed before the CoC? | Whether approval of related party transactions by the CoC under Section 28(1)(f) of IBC amounts to approval of such expenses as CIRP cost under CIRP Regulations 31 and 34? – Lotus Auto Engineering Ltd. Vs. Dinkar T. Venkatasubramaniam and Ors. – NCLAT New Delhi

A claim arising from discounting of invoices or trade receivables/ factoring is an operational debt under Section 5(21) of the IBC and not a financial debt | The mere assignment of operational debts to a third party, including a financial institution or factor, does not convert the nature of the debt into a financial debt | The nature of a debt under the IBC is determined by the substance of the underlying transaction and not by the identity of the party asserting the claim – Canbank Factors Ltd. Vs. Brijesh Singh Bhaduria, RP of RCI Industries & Technologies Ltd. and Ors. – NCLAT New Delhi
Discounting of invoices or trade receivables/ factoring is an Operational Debt under Section 5(21) of the IBC, NCLAT

When a notice of dispute has been given with details of contract and subsequent execution of settlement between the parties, the Adjudicating Authority (NCLT) has not to admit application under Section 9 of IBC – F.M.T. Engineers Pvt. Ltd. Vs. Raj Kesari Rocks Pvt. Ltd. – NCLAT New Delhi
Even when recovery certificate proceedings are pending before DRT, CIRP can be initiated under Section 7 of IBC – P. Narotham Rao Vs. Indian Bank and Anr. – NCLAT Chennai

Sale of inventory worth several crores at a fraction of its value, based on unsubstantiated claims of damage and without proper reporting to banks or insurers, is to be treated as an undervalued transaction under Section 45 of the IBC, 2016 – Seatel Electronics India Pvt. Ltd. Vs. Pankaj Sharma and Ors. – NCLT Jaipur Bench

During liquidation proceedings, the IBC does not provide any shield against the examination or investigation of the Corporate Debtor by authorities, including the conduct of a forensic audit under the banking and criminal law framework – Bhavarlal Mangilal Jain and Anr. Vs. Indian Overseas Bank and Ors. – NCLT Ahmedabad Bench

Delay in filing bankruptcy applications can be condoned, especially when such delays are justified and do not prejudice the rights of the parties involved – Canara Bank Vs. Sarita Devi Jhawar – NCLT Ahmedabad Bench
Recovery rate through the IBC, 2016 and SARFAESI in Financial Year 2025 | Performance of the Insolvency Code
